PMRpro.bio: I've had PMR for over 15 years - so I think I'm entitled to regard myself as a pro especially since I have a background of a lifetime of medical research and allied work (I'm not a medic though)! I had 5 years untreated and have had heading for 10 years on pred with a variety of ups and downs on the way to 12mg/day at present. I've experienced a selection of different medical systems as well as probably reading more textbooks and publications about PMR (in particular) and GCA than most GPs have on the way.

DorsetLady.bio:
GCA diagnosed April 2012 (age 65).  Remission September 2016. Hanging around hoping to help others as I was helped early days.

Mis-diagnosed for 18 months  between October 2010-April 2012 -  original problems pains in shoulders/biceps. Because ESR was deemed satisfactory GCA/PMR discounted by GP. Diagnosed as frozen shoulder, and any resultant head/neck pains attributed to that. Worsening fatigue was attributed to age and caring for husband. No Pred taken therefore.

Correct diagnosis from Ophthalmologist in A&E after irrevocable sight loss in right eye following 4 days of sight disturbances, specifically blurriness in right eye - started at bottom of eye moving over rest of eye until no sight remaining.

Readings at diagnosis  – ESR 58, CRP 26.2. 
Started 80mg Pred.  Took 4 and half years to get to zero; total time of GCA 6 years approximately. 
Expected side effects from Pred, slightly raised BP levels, slightly raised glaucoma levels (no action required for either).
Steroid induced (?) cataract on remaining eye successfully replaced October 2014 when at 6mg. Initial weight gain, lost at lower levels, and more significantly once off the steroids. 

Widowed in 2013 (on 46th Wedding Anniversary) which although not ideal in its timing fortunately did not seem to affect my recovery, no flares of GCA, although ESR was raised mainly due to excess stress over previous few months. Late hubby in HM Forces, I worked for MOD for 30 years. Two children, four grandchildren.

Finally getting my life back post GCA and enjoying it to the best of my ability. Been to New Zealand three times to see daughter and family - 2014, 2017, 2024. Hope to make more in future.

July 2018 had total knee replacement (left);  January 2019 total hip replacement (right); February 2020 total shoulder replacement (left). Not blaming steroids, had OA before GCA, and unfortunately a family trait on maternal side.

Lady in banner is Freyja, Viking Goddess.

As name suggests, I live in Dorset!  But perhaps I should be renamed Titanium Lady 🤣😂🤣

More info  - see the FAQ under GCA  Members Experiences - DorsetLady’s Story

SheffieldJane.bio:
I am based in the U.K. I was diagnosed with GCA /LVV in April 2020 after having PMR since early 2016. I had got down to 3 mgs Prednisalone and PMR seemed to be in remission. I was diagnosed by means of Ultrasound Scan and a new headache. I am currently on 10 mgs of Prednisalone and Tocilizumab weekly injections.
My other conditions include Cervical Spondylosis, Graves Disease and Osteoarthritis.
My professional background includes HR Management, Equality and Diversity Policies, Person Centred Counselling. Specialisms, Disability, Victims of Crime, Domestic Violence, Dementia ( cared for mum).
Married with 3 Adult children and 4 grandchildren. All living in Australia except for son who lives with us.

HeronNS.bio:
Hi, I live in Nova Scotia, Canada.  Diagnosed with polymyalgia rheumatica in June 2015, after more than a year of increasing pain.  Medical complications include subsequent discovery that I have what they call "low bone mass" although exercise, diet and supplements are improving that, and recently learned that sarcoidosis (discovered through biopsy when I was in my mid-thirties) may also have some relevance to my life today.  Have been at about 2 mg prednisone for about two years (writing this 2019) after initial start dose of 15 mg.  Update October '19 appear to be successfully approaching 1 mg.  Have had to slow down DSNS taper by doing each taper twice.  
March 2020 tapering to zero, Zero is "new dose".  :)
June 2020 at zero pred.  
My PMR journey has been bookended by injuries to my right knee.  In 2014 I sustained a tibial plateau fracture.  A couple of months after returning to work I developed fullblown PMR symptoms although I was not diagnosed until 2015.  And I have just, 31/5/20, fallen (tripped over an object in my home, my stupidity) and smashed the knee down as hard as I could.  Nothing broken but hurt enough to need a brace for a couple of weeks.   As I'm retired now I won't be overdoing things too soon this time.  :)
Actually the other knee is the bad one, after an apparently minor twist.  May be headed to eventual knee replacement but I think the problem rests with treating it as though it was osteoarthritis when it was really a damaged ligament or tendon.  gradually healing now that I've changed my behaviour.  Much of info in my blog.  https://anhaga1.com/
Zero pred lasted a month, the final week of which brought return of PMR pain, which pred sorted.  Now back at 2 mg. :(
End of January 2021, unprecedented flare preceded by dramatic rise in CRP.  Up to 10 mg, and in process of quick step down to about 5 mg.   Which has not worked so far (mid-Feb).
Sept 2021 at around 4 mg pred, to my chagrin.  However knee injuries have subsided and I can take proper walks again, good for the mental outlook!
Will this saga ever end?  Interestingly I found after my Shingrix shot at end of July I found it easier to taper for a while.  I have recently had the second, five and a half months after the first, and am feeling pretty good.  Tapering to 2.5.  Another thing which happened was my doctor sent me for morning cortisol test and result (about 60 hours after last pred dose) was right in the middle of the normal range.  And CRP is lowest it's ever been, first time I was told it was normal (3 point something).  Did the adjuvant in Shingrix help?  Footnote to vaccines:  had Moderna as second booster and since then have been very comfortably at 2.5 mg pred and tapering to 2.  Very slow progress, but progress neverthless.  PfizerX3   had been pretty much non-events, but Moderna, unexpectedly, hit me much like Shingrix.  
April 2023. Had Pfizer "Spring dose" a couple of weeks ago. Hardly even aware where the shot went in. Current pred dose 1.5 seems okay so far. I would have preferred a non-mRNA vaccine this time but Novavax only option and it's incredibly inconvenient to access.  Did not want Moderna again. I suppose there's no connection really, but it seems a bit more than coincidence that inconsequential heart symptoms quite rapidly became concerning a short while after first Moderna booster.  I didn't think to make the connection until after having Moderna bivalent. Now at glacial pace I've been undergoing various tests and there's a referral to a cardiologist. This all got underway last June (2022) and in December I got diagnosis of aortic regurgitation, later slightly glossed by my GP when he said no one part of my heart seems worse than any other. I have a "tired" heart. So not willing to stress it any more than is good for it.  2024 not seen specialist yet. GP has referred me to someone else. (Note: 2nd Jan '25, no cardiologist visit yet. GP re-referred me to different specialist, but even that was seven months ago)
May be at zero pred, time will tell. Writing this mid May 2024 and have not taken pred since Feb 1st. But broke my wrist about ten days ago so not sure what will happen next. PMR developed after a (much less serious) tibial plateau fracture. 
End of November, 2024, PMR still in remission. But....
I'm actually taking pred again in what I hope will be a successful way to deal with what appears to be sarcoid patches on my skin. The good part is since I started (5 mg, now 4, to continue reducing) no new patches have appeared, and it's a lot easier to take a pill than smear on ineffective too-weak hydrocortisone ointment.  The bad part is the said too-weak ointment still needs to be used on what I have, and those patches still exist though very slowly fading.  I really hope I won't need to ask for a prescription ointment, and I am tapering more slowly than instructed because I don't want to open the door again. 
It was accidental that I realized what this skin thing was, because it had bothered me off and on for many years, it would come and go, usually with the help of a prescription ointment then followed up with a good skin cream, but it was not a problem all those years I was on pred!  Never any diagnosis given, just treated as an idiopathic rash.  (Sarcoidosis was diagnosed through biopsy of a lymph node when I was about 35, although I never thought I had any symptoms.)  It reappeared about two months after achieving pred zero, although somewhat timidly at first and started as very sensitive skin when I was on my final taper to half a mg and then off. I remembered it was when at that very same dose in 2020, just before an unsuccessful first fling with zero, that I was cutting all the labels out of my clothes! 
2 Jan, '25, starting a new pred protocol, 5 mg until skin cleared up completely, then a slow taper, hopefully back to 2 mg. Dr provided me with what should be generous enough prescription refills. (PMR remains quiescent!)

SnazzyD.bio:
Diagnosed with GCA in 2017 aged 54 out of the blue and was started on 60mg Pred. I was a nurse and manager of a cancer support centre, mum to two young adults with live-in elderly relative, I was fit and active . I had also got over breast cancer surgery, radio therapy and chemo in 2004.  Life as I knew it just stopped over 48 hours and I never made it back to work which broke my heart but I’m learning a different way. It’s been a long process of reassessing, healing and self discovery. Feb 2020 I was on 0.5mg. Came off Pred Aug 2020. The after effects are muscle loss and tendiopathy which is being worked on with specific exercises. I also have lifelong cyclical neutropaenia (not connected to GCA or PMR) meaning my neutrophil count drops every three weeks possibly also autoimmune but they don’t know.  
I have been off Pred since Aug 2020 and my recovery has continued rather than ending with the Pred. My energy and adrenal function were slow to return and a few times I had to take a rescue dose of Pred for adrenal crisis. During this time however, I had Covid 8 times. I came off Pred during long Covid the first time. The 4th time July 2022 took 7 months of feeling really low physically for 7 months. None of these caused a flare of GCA. It has taken until April 2023 to feel like my muscles have started to repair after Pred for 3.5 years. This was a depressing surprise that muscle resilience didn’t bounce back and that it is a long term project. Unrealistic expectations from medical messaging didn’t help.

Blearyeyed.bio:
Years of struggle for a diagnosis for all of my symptoms and flare ups meant I didn't have a full picture of my chronic health issues until my 50th year.
I am now trying to walk the medical minefield of discovering how to get the best treatment I can for the varied and uncommon conditions I have while coping with the lack of knowledge in the Healthcare System for my conditions.
Twenty five years on from my conditions impacting on daily life .... Time is ticking ,  I have now been diagnosed with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (Classic Like), Chronic Dysautonomia (in the form of SNRT and POTs ) , Tachycardia, Atrial Fibrillation, Recurrent cardiac and cerebral vasospasms have decided to develop off the back of this Autonomic Dysfunction , Fibromyalgia, IBS -C and gastrointestinal dysmotility, Functional Vitamin B12 Deficiency Anaemia and Folate Deficiency with Neurological complications came next  which provoked checks and diagnosis of Pancreatic Enzyme Insufficiency and Familial HyperCholesteroleimia, Chronic Pain , Fatigue , Full Chronic Migraine Spectrum and Cluster Headaches and Eye issues along with a syndrome for every letter of the alphabet triggered by the above ( if you will let me have queasy for Q) and as an artist I cannot afford to be Blearyeyed.

Open for all the advice and support I can get , and willing to give any help I can to fellow sufferers on the long and stressful road to diagnosis and coping with getting the best out of each day with the ,"New Normal" of Chronic illness.
Good luck to all and let's laugh , cry and work together for a better way to good health. Love Auntie Bee

Longtimer.bio:
I was diagnosed with Polymyalgia about the same week as my 60th birthday....2011
Rheumatologist said drop quickly using this chart, and you will be off steroids in two years...I battled to follow her way and changed to another Rheumatologist in same hospital, he was pretty much the same...in fact worse.  I now do things myself as regards lowering pred, and doctor prescribes for me.....I react quite badly to all meds....so it has been a struggle from the start....
Have excellent Rheumatologist at long last.2021..(10 years)
I have now had a Pet/CT (May 2021) scan showed no LVV or PM R inflammation.....was at 5 mg for the scan.  . Have gone back to 7 mg.....so now going to have cortisol blood test to see if adrenals are capable of working......still have severe fatigue....tingling feet, weakness in legs....balance problems.
Very big struggle now at 7 mg, tried lowering to 6.5mg, no energy to even get out of chair....
First cortisol reading was 92, so have adrenal suporession, have red steroid card and wear a bracelet stating adrenal pro blems, in case of collapse.  
Now having second cortisol test to see if any change....
Surprising results....reading now 166......so going in the right direction...very pleased with that....Will try lowering in a few weeks after Christmas....
Had another cortisol test in late June, this time dropped to 124, no explanation for this.....
D exa scan not good either....already know I have Osteoporosis, but spine reading 10 % worse........I
Now lowering very slowly on 6 mg.....

Constance13.bio:
Constance.   28.07.1939
I have lived in Germany for 48 years.
In 2012 I suddenly became very stiff, unusual pains, difficulty in walking, couldn't climb stairs, etc.  Then one day I couldn't move my arms up to comb my hair.  Time for a doctor, I thought!
Dr said "I know what it is but we must wait for blood test results".  (ESR 87, CRP 35). Diagnosis Polymyalgia Rheumatica.  I laughed - never heard of it!  Was given Pred (30mg) - all pain gone within six hours.  Wow (I thought) if you have to have an illness this is the one - one tablet and all pain and discomfort gone!  Didn't think that for long!!!
Over the next few months ESR & CRP kept rising and rising.  Eventually rose to ESR 132, CRP 100.  Nobody knew what was happening - I was still on Pred.  I eventually collapsed and was hospitalised for 12 days.
All this was 7 years ago.  Ups and downs since then.  Now on 4mg.  PMR has been very aggressive.  Recently told I would probably have to stay on Pred for life.
Age has caught up on me -  Seronegative Polyarthritis , Gout, GERD - among other things.  
Life is good though, pain and discomfort manageable.  Easy to deal with this pesky illness because of all the help I have received from HU.  This is a wonderful forum.
xxxxxx

Yellowbluebell.bio:
I am a 58 year old wife, mum and nanny.  I have 2 grown up and married girls  and an 9 year old grandson and a one year old granddaughter.   
I gave up work as a barrister in 2010 to look after  my husband who broke his back as a fireman.   My first love has always been mental health law and I took a break from the courts and became the head of a NHS legal team for a mental health trust for 7 years but returned  to being a barrister specialising in mental health cases.  I have returned to working  a few days a week but I choose his much I do.

I was diagnosed with pmr in oct 2018 after probably suffering from it for 2 years at least.  I only started tapering in late feb but being allowed by rheumy and gp to do it at my own pace.  

I have been making and selling quilts since giving up work and although I now  seem to work more than before I  still enjoy quilting even when tired!!

tangocharlie.bio: Live in Leeds, England.  Diagnosed PMR in 2012 at age of 51 but probably had it at least a year before that.  Recently added spinal fractures to my list of woes which they are saying is due to steroids, but I'm not convinced. It's been a bumpy PMR journey and I've had a few setbacks such as rheumatologists saying I was too young to have PMR, which is when luckily I found this forum as he was so wrong.  Still have it in 2025, 13+ years later which is another debunk of the 'it burns itself out in 2 years myth' doctors trot out.  As well as being on a high dose of steroids I'm now trialling Hydroxychloraquine whch seems to be helping. Before that tried Methotrexate injections which I reacted badly to, Leflunomide which was ineffective and also Sulfasalazine. Had depo-medrone steroid injections as an alternative to Pred for a few years with mixed success (probably) due to inexperienced rheumatologist.  Also had adrenal problems several times.  Used to volunteer on PMRGCAuk Helpline and still help run PMRGCAuk's Yorkshire support group.  My personal mission having had such a hard time is to improve our care and treatment and support others with PMR/LVV/GCA and now also want ot spread the word about lookingafter your bones before it's too late

Telian.bio:
74 year old female diagnosed with GCA in March 2014 via positive ultrasound, had negative TAB. Breast cancer in August 2014 and PMR in November 2016.
Tapered slowly throughout due to withdrawal symptoms from first taper.   Got down to 3mg in September 2018 and couldn’t get lower.  Went through adrenal recovery for 8 months - not nice.   Following big house move and husband seriously ill had a flare December 2019 -  increased pred to 10mg then 15mg then 20mg.   After 6 weeks tapered to 15mg then 10mg with minimal withdrawals- now stuck on 8mg. Adrenal resurgence seems to be on the verge again. September 2021, managed to get to 7.5mg Adrenals making  a comeback with vengeance.  Adrenal symptoms lasted 8 months again.  Rheumie says it’s possible can happen earlier 2nd time around! March 2023 and nearly at 6.5mg.

Kendrew.bio:
I was a 61yr old woman when diagnosed in MAY 2019. Started my working life as a nurse at 'Jimmys' in Leeds. Later, I did my B.Ed in special needs at Hull  and have spent the rest of my life working in the Early Years Foundation Stage of education. 
I've felt pretty much alone in muddling my way through this condition up to press and have been very unwell from side effects of steroids more than the actual condition.  I started off on 40mg prednisolone and I'm now down to 2.5mg. God willing, I'll be off the steroids by the end of the year. Having been off work for 15mths, I'm now hoping to return to my job as a nursery teaching assistant in Sept. It's been an incredibly scary journey but somehow I've found ways to get through the worst days and the awful symptoms & side effects of the steroids,  and discovered strategies that have helped me. If I can help anyone by sharing this information,  I'd be very glad to.
OCT 2020- How naive was I?? Since writing the above paragraph I've definitely re-educated myself about this condition....with a little....no actually,  a lot!.....of help from more informed people on here! Biggest lessons learned....PMR usually 'active' much longer than you're told or want to believe. It's not a race to get off pred as quickly as possible...and respect both the condition and the medication because patience is the key! I'm currently back up to 7.5mg and doing things much more slowly!! I'm also back at work, in school and I'm being VERY careful to pace myself, but not always easy to judge it correctly,  so had a few blips....but so far, so good. Hope this alerts 'newbies' to be aware of some of the inaccurate advice medical professionals may give you!
NOV 2020:- I've had a whole half term back in school with my 26 nursery class children,  and how joyful and therapeutic it's been. However,  the flipside of this is that the increase in physical activity has meant an increase in my steroid dose. What began as 2.5mg in Sep has now increased to 12.5mgt now! It was inevitable and expected but a 2nd lockdown has resulted in me being told to stay home for 4wks! Another knock back, but hey ho.....what doesn't kill you, makes you stronger!
APRIL 2021- Still not back at work. Currently on 10mg pred. Initially I was 'staying safe' as higher dose of steroids put me back into immuno-compromised category..... the higher dose also then made me feel unwell again, causing head pain, fatigue and the other usual suspects! 
I'm about to begin a 3rd and final attempt to return to work at the end of May but I do have concerns and reservations as I don't want to lose all the improvements in my health that have been gained only because I've not been working!!
Watch this space!
MAY 2021- With a very heavy heart, I've had to make the most difficult decision to give up working and I'm applying for medical retirement.  I simply can't work and stay well. Feel so sad but know it's for the best.
OCT 2021- I'm now officially medically retired as of 2wks ago. I've had my 'goodbye assembly' at school and was incredibly emotional. The Head, the children and the parents, all said such kind things. 
I'm slowly beginning to adjust to life at home and feeling more positive and motivated to explore what the next chapter of my life may have in store for me! I'm able to focus completely on my own health & well-being now and I'm already feeling some benefits. It's been a challenging transition for me to manage but I'm looking forward to 'covid-safer' times when I'll be able to go into nursery again as a regular volunteer helper. There's much to look forward to as a new door opens. 
APRIL 2022- Well, covid is still ever present and affecting many of the choices I make regarding where I go and who I see. Sadly, I've not felt it safe enough to go into school yet, particularly as covid just seems to be repeatedly infecting my colleagues over & over again! I'm definitely feeling more settled though with regard to being medically retired, and much more accepting of the situation now that I'm realising what a positive impact its having on my health.....knowing I can now choose what my day will entail based on how I'm feeling has removed all the pressure and stress that a demanding job working with a Nursery class of 24 under 5's can produce. If I'm awake all night (as often happens) I no longer fret about needing to get to sleep because I've to be up at 6.30am for work. If I have a bad day when I'm feeling particularly fatigued, achey or just generally unwell, I can rest for as long as necessary and not be anxious about having to ring in sick!!
Just knowing I can now focus completely on my own health & well-being has facilitated a definite improvement on both my physical well-being and my mental well-being.  Don't misunderstand me....I still experience challenging days but now I have the time to manage them more effectively and make better choices.
Back in Jan, I developed a severe case of Urticaria....an unpleasant itchy skin rash that manifested with raised, angry patches of hives all over my arms, chest, trunk, thighs & legs. It appeared completely out of the blue and my new (and very knowledgeable & sympathetic) GP explained that this happens as a result of an allergic reaction to something...I've yet to discover what!! To my complete horror,  I was advised to increase my steroids from the 6mg I was currently on up to 30mg!.... the antihistamines alone weren't improving things. However  within 3wks I was back down at 6mg and together with 2 types of high strength prescription antihistamines the rash began to diminish.  It took at least 6wks for my skin to fully recover and now I make sure I pay as much attention to my skin-health as my overall health. 
I'm about to taper from 5½mg of pred to 5mg in the next week and at the moment  my health is fairly stable and constant. I truly believe this is down to not working anymore, having hugely reduced stress levels and directing my focus onto 'looking after me'!!
MAY 2022 - Today is 11th May and after a long 3yrs I've finally made it into school again! With no covid infections currently evident and a lovely Nursery garden for outdoor teaching I decided there would not be a better time to make a return to the Nursery class that's been such a big part of my life for the best part of 15yrs! I did not return as a teacher though....I returned as a volunteer helper! It was so joyful and upifting. I felt I was exactly where I was meant to be. .....and the best part was that I had none of those pressures, responsibilities or stressors that would normally accompany my job. The children were such good therapy  and I truly loved and embraced getting to know them all. How privileged, lucky and blessed am I to have had today!
I definitely intend to go in every week when possible and although I'm definitely tired now, I feel as long as I have a few days afterwards to rest and chill, there's no reason why I can't volunteer again. 
PMR can sometimes feel cruel...even brutal at times but today has been another little triumph and re-affirmed my belief that many good things are still possible ....you just have to trust in the process.
Watch this space to see how I get on!
July 2022 - Well, I made it into school for 4wks before 2 of the Nursery staff tested positive for covid...again!! This meant I had to temporarily refrain from going in till all clear, but with the summer break upon us, this won't  be till Sept now. 
I've had a wonderful holiday in Devon and I'm now beginning my next taper from 5mg down to 4.5mg. (I've been stable on 5mg for approx 7wks.)
Dec 22 - My health has had a few minor 'glitches' which fortunately have been resolved fairly easily and I'm now on 4mg of prednisolone and feeling pretty good most of the time. 
Approximately 6wks ago though I had another covid booster.  It was the Pfizer 'combo' one and although I suffered no obvious, immediate adverse affects (as I had with my previous Moderna one) I noticed that over the following 2wks my palpitations were beginning to re-emerge.  I have always had a history of ectopic beats which although uncomfortable & alarming at times, are actually harmless.  A beta blocker (propranolol) brought them back under control after the steroids seemed to trigger them off again and up till this most recent booster, everything had been ok. They gradually became worse and this time made me feel more unwell.... breathless on exertion and more  fatigue than usual.  Blood tests ruled out anaemia, diabetes and thyroid as possible causes and also heart failure. 
They have significantly improved but I'm still seeing my cardiologist to rule out anything else.
On a more positive note...I'm now going into nursery class every week as a volunteer helper and it's bringing me such joy.
MARCH 2023.
Just had my 6monthly rheumatology appointment with Dr. Fiona Coath and all is good. My blood tests are ALL within normal parameters for the second time in a row and she's happy with my tapering regime. All the hard work ensuring I have a healthy diet and regular (appropriate) exercise seems to be paying off. 
I've missed approximately 4wks of helping out in nursery class again, as covid and flu are sweeping through the school. Hope to be back after Easter now.
I'm currently on 3½mgs and about to start next ½mg taper from 3½mgs to 3mgs. Fingers crossed.

123-go.bio:
I was diagnosed in February 2018 with Polymyalgia Rheumatica. My symptoms reduced dramatically two or three days after I began an initial dose of 15mg Prednisolone with gradual tapering. After a relapse in December 2018 my dose returned to 15mg. gradually  tapering until November 2019 when I developed double vision. This was corrected with a fresnel prism fitted to my glasses and again a return to 15mg. The double vision has improved and I'm currently taking 5mg Pred but regular clinic checks/consultations have been postponed due to the current pandemic.

Now April 2021 and I'm on 2.5mg Pred  plus 10mg Leflunomide after being diagnosed with asymptomatic large vessel vasculitis ( aortitis). There was a blip at this time when I was seen by a rheumatology research fellow whose management plan stated I should move on from 2.5mg pred daily to 2.5mg on alternate days for one month then 2.5mg every third day. I wrote to the department expressing my concern at this plan and it was changed to a rather more acceptable plan of 2mg daily for one month then 2mg and 1mg (alternate days)/for a further month when the tapering plan became 2mg/1mg/1mg on a three day cycle. 

At my review in April’22 with a locum rheumatologist his answer to my reporting tingling and numbness in toes was to diagnose “widespread osteoarthritis including osteoarthritis of hand, feet and knee”. He said I “may feel better by proper shoes and shoe support  with a referral to a podiatrist for biochemical support” if need be. All this was by looking at my hands and feet. He said my PMR had “gone” and I should stop taking Prednisolone. I was appalled but I didn’t waste my breath in any discussion: however,  I couldn’t leave without telling someone about this experience and followed that up with a letter to the specialist nurse and eventually another review with a competent rheumatologist who continued with pred tapering and disregarded ‘‘widespread osteoarthritis “. I continue to walk several times a week for an hour+ each time and garden, knit, sew, and occasional craft work with no pain in feet, knees or hands. 

How time flies! It is now October 2023 and after a fairly uneventful 2+ years I am tapering very slowly to 0.5mg prednisolone daily. I have to admit that I’m a little uneasy about taking the final step to zero and ‘letting go’ of my friend prednisolone.  
The aortitis was followed up with a second PET-CT in January this year which showed there had been no increase in any aortic dilation and a subsequent echocardiogram showed the aortic root was of normal size and the arch and ascending aorta appear to have normal dimensions.
I was therefore considered to be ‘stable’. 😂😂 and continue with 10mg Leflunomide daily.

March 2024. After 6 years on Prednisolone I have tapered to zero. I took my last 0.5mg at the end of January but will remain on 10mg Leflunomide daily for ‘a while’.

Jackoh.bio:
Started with symptoms of aching arms , unable to fasten bra and difficulty turning head to drive. This suddenly developed to flu type symptoms,  feeling exhausted and very unwell after a short walk.  Doctor diagnosed PMR and did blood tests. These were quite unremarkable- ESR 18 CRP -1 As ESR though slightly above average was started on 15 mg of steroids. Wonderful result with no problems tapering until 11 mg. Felt exhausted on 11 mg and when trying to taper to 10mg - a lot of pain so tried 10 and a half. Pain gradually got worse and went up to 14 mg. At 14 mg caught a bad cold and GCA symptoms ( boring type pains of a hot rod  in side of head) started. GP stated that I hadn’t got GCA but went up to 21 mg before these pains subsided. Saw Dr Hughes privately who diagnosed cranial
GCA. Have had a real problem reducing , Dr Hughes introduced lefludomide but this did not seem to help tapering. After peripheral neuropathy in legs ( 2019 ) I stopped lefludomide and started reducing without. At present (2020) trying to reduce from 11 and a half to 11 mg ( second time) Now in August 2023 I have been reducing very very slowly and at present am doing a very very slow reduction from 6.5 to 6.0. I have not been taking any steroid sparers.

Pixix.bio: Diagnosed December 2019, & now still tapering! I was diagnosed one week later with prediabetes. Already suffer from fibromyalgia, 15 years. Have some residual car crash injuries as well. Have lung weakness, prone to chest infections & am allergic to a lot of things. My Prediabetes was steroid induced & now reversed through keto diet. Osteoarthritis has worsened, and spread to toes, thumbs, hands! In the latest year or so I’ve added Raynaud’s phenomenon, Essential Tremor, Sciatica, Trochanteric Bursitis, Vertigo & Hypermobility to my little ‘collection’!

Bcol.bio:
Hi There. Osteoarthritis in the 1980's which became really bad in both knees in the 90’s when I really struggled with work, I was a teacher and, on my feet, pretty much all day and at times found it extremely hard just getting joints to work even to get out of bed. As I was relatively young, I had a real struggle to get the NHS to even think about joint replacement, they weren't really interested unless you were in your 70's. Physio and tablets is all that was on offer initially.  Full replacement in 1999, brilliant. Ill health retirement in 2001. OA in knees, feet, and hands but relatively under control. PMR in June 2020, which was a bit of a poo, pain so bad I ended up at the walk (in my case carry) in centre for the night. The doc there missed it, thought it was an OA flare which did not make sense to me, but was feeling too befuddled to query it. My own doctors picked it up the following week. I had no idea what PMR was at that point. Started on 15mg/day, quickly moved to 30mg/day for 5 days, then 25mg/day for 5 days, 20mg/day for two weeks. Did lots of research, found this incredible site. Now starting long tapers. Half way through the taper from 7mg to 6mg (June 2021) and at the moment all going well – plenty of time for that to change of course. 
Update 11/08/2021
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome deciding to be grumpy so chat with doc and Pred back up to 10mg, from 5mg, for three weeks, then usual (for me) 5 week (minimum) taper down again in hopes that it will bring it under control again without the need for surgery.
Update 31/08/2022
In reality things are going well. Still using my modified DL .5mg five-week taper, longer if necessary. Had a query DVT in January, sent to hospital, had full check but nothing to worry about. I had an extremely painless right leg at the beginning of April 2022 where I had excruciating pain down my thigh, knee and shin. My shin felt like the shin bone was split down the middle with both halves rubbing against each other. Virtually unable to walk. PMR ruled out by myself and Doctor and referred onto an Orthopaedic specialist. Rested for about three weeks- no walks – No definitive result from the various doctors and pain etc eventually disappeared. Walking back to normal. Two funny instances with right leg this year and still, sometimes, it doesn’t seem to do, straight away, what my brain tells it to. We will see if anything else transpires.
Went back to 5mg from 3.5mg end of May/June for two months and now in second week of 4.5mg to 4.0mg
I keep a spreadsheet diary of medication taken and in stock, makes ordering easy, and record BP daily and weight and Blood Sugar levels weekly. I also note anything that is relevant – covid tests etc. I send a copy of the diary to the doc whenever I order Pred or Omeprazole. Not actually seen a doctor since the hospital incident but they are always there for telephone consultations which are usually the same or following day. She/he organises blood tests and a DEXA scan when requested and supplies the prescription for the Pred I tell her I need. Not sure any of that is, in reality right, but she is happy to leave me to it and it does make my life easy. She always tells me to ring at any time if necessary.
Managing to walk the bowwows again and generally manage to get around 5 - 6 or so miles done most mornings, either flat or a bit hilly depending on how I and they feel.
No formal medical education other than paediatric first aider, indoors and outdoors for many years.
Living in the North West of England, Rochdale/Wardle area of Greater Manchester.

Update 14/10/2024

Tapered slowly down and now been on zero Pred since the 1st September 2024 and so far all going well on the PMNR side. 

CTS is not so good and having significant problems with both wrists/fingers. Pain and lack of feeling in hands and fingertips makes completing certain day to day tasks difficult. Been on waiting list for surgery in both wrists since January 2024.

The back/leg problem only appears at times so fortunately I do not have to cope with it all the time.

Update January 2025
Took my last Pred in September 2024 and so far no problems regarding my PMR. still early days but it's looking hopeful that's it's gone for the time being. 
CTS is a different matter, still awaiting surgery and hands and wrists not in a good place regarding pain, which can go right up the arm, and the lack of feeling in fingers which can/does make doing things "interesting".

Grammy80.bio:
I'm an 84-year-old gal who lives in Indiana, USA, with family in Indiana and Nova Scotia. I had lived alone in Maine for four years since 2016. In August 2019, I was diagnosed with GCA and left blind in my left eye. I was misdiagnosed initially, or that probably wouldn't have happened.
In 2020, I experienced a few flares that affected my right eye.  At that point, I had to decide and truly could not be by myself anymore.  At that time, I returned to Indiana and was sharing a home with my husband.  It has relieved me from all stress regarding driving to appointments to meet my most basic needs, like eating healthier and not being afraid of being alone and falling again.  He is happy to have the company. We have been married for 40+ years, and there have been a few separations.  He is 81, I am 84...we are a couple of OLD friends.  Here is to the future, whatever it may hold for however long~!!  I also have epilepsy and the steroids can water down seizure meds, seizure-free for 48 years.
February 16, 2023: I'm now down to 3.5 mg of prednisone and thrilled with that.  I'm beginning to think my adrenal glands are kicking in.  I have more energy, although I will have to work on strengthening it through the winter.  I've been pretty sedentary but I'm delighted to think my GCA may be quiet.   Shhhhhhh!     Onward and downward....slowly.
I got down to 1 mg plus TCZ and then things flew apart.  I experienced a bowel perforation, escaped a colostomy, and then had quite a flare.  I'm presently taking 20 mg and hope to get back on my TCZ in a week.  My right eye is a bit blurry, but I'm hoping it is the excessive prednisone I was given when I had the flare: 500 mg IV for three days and then 60 mg tablets.  It is quite a ride.....but it will settle down, I'm sure when it is darn good and ready.
Wow, that bowel perforation was the fall of 2023...and until I reread my bio....I didn't recall how many times I flared and took 60mg.  The memory can be kind.
June 2024....I got to zero, not that -0- was a goal of mine, I just wanted quality of life.  After one month, at the end of July 2024, the headache started and got worse; though I could chew, the pain in the jaw joint was pretty intense, and I had shooting pains through my blind eye.  We went to the emergency room, and I received 500 mg IV of Prednisolone, but it was kept overnight.  The pain had lessened (A CLUE), but when the rheumy came in the AM, he sent me home with a script for 60mg per day, only to be taken if the pain came back. It was back with a vengeance in 36 hours.  I saw the rheumy two days later and he cut it to 5mg and wanted the neuro-ophthalmologist to see my eye on a dosage of less than 60mg so that nothing would be masked.  I saw him in two days and he immediately ordered 1250 mg IV infusions for the next three days.  I had lost some peripheral vision in my right eye.  After the infusions, I've been taking 60 mg a day...spacey.  I've seen both doctors since and am continuing on 60 mg per day.  Though the neuro has never, until the infusions, gotten involved in the dosage, he will now be determining that because he can see in, around, and behind my eye.  Now I have some nerve pain involvement, but it is tolerable. I just want to see what I can see, and I'll be happy.  
July/August/September 2024   My tremors became more severe, I had balance issues..but I attributed everything to being on 60 mg per day.  Then I couldn't seem to walk correctly,  legs so stiff, numb, urinated beyond measure.....Finally, I felt strongly that this was something other than 60mg daily.  I'd been up and down the pred scale for five years.  My neuro-ophthalmologist told me to see a neurologist, and on 9/24/24, I was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.  Now, I'm searching for information and help, doing all that is in my power.

Celtic.bio:
I was diagnosed with both PMR and GCA in 2007 after PMR had remained undiagnosed for the previous year during which I spent 3-4 months unable to get out of bed except to attend hospital rheumatology appointments by ambulance and wheelchair.
Commenced on 40mg Prednisolone and now (June 2012) almost at zero. 
Set up the PMRGCAuk Surrey Support Group in July 2011.
Hospitalised with severe mitral regurgitation in late 2018 due to leaking valve suddenly moving from long-term  slight leak to severe.  Medicated and discharged after 5 days.  
Sole kidney since teens suddenly deteriorated in 2007. at present stable chronic kidney disease with between 38-44% function.

Koalajane.bio:
I was diagnosed with PMR in March 2017. Three months after I was diagnosed with type 2diabetes. By the following January my diabetes went into remission and has stayed that way. I am off medication for the diabetes and on a LCHF diet and walk over 10,000 steps each day. I am still on prednisolone. I have also been diagnosed with macular oedema and have Lucentis injections every 6 weeks at the moment. My opthamologist tells me it is because I don’t control my sugars although my last hba1c was 35! I am not sure what else I can do other than try and drop my steroids as much as is possible. I am now on Eylea injections every 2 months and I am waiting to have laser treatment which I am told will mean I do not need so many injections,
My current dose of pred is 8.5mg, I got to 4mg and flared so went up and trying to go back down again. I tried taking my pred at 2 a.m. but it was detrimental to my diabetes. 
I am now on 6mg of prednisolone reducing slowly by .25mg each month

cycli.bio:
Conclusions up to the present. 
I think I am getting a handle on these two conditions and when it all started. These latter chronic symptoms have been present for nearly three years. Neck and shoulder stiffness, muscle contraction  numbness in feet, legs and joints and bad headaches mainly from the temples and across the top of the head. Up until recently I have managed them through a combination of aggressive cycling, general manual work on the farm, osteopath, sport massage and some pills. Conditions like broken bones, DVT, and PE in both lungs had to be medically treated. The earlier signs of cramping and badly contracted muscle and neck stiffness go back some ten years. The osteopath and masseuse were always perplexed at how tight my muscles seemed to be, so much so it slightly pulled my spine out of its proper alignment.
In September 2017 I had an horrific crash which left me with broken bones, some skin loss and a seriously broken body. Something like Chris Froomes’ crash but with head injuries. It would have been nice to have the medical help Ineos provided him, but us ordinary mortals just have to struggle by ourselves. Nothing I could have done to prevent it. Brazing on the front forks dropout failed and the front wheel separated from the bike at 35mph downhill. Instant black out and no memory of the impact thank goodness. Lucky to be alive as I was  cycling with a good buddy who called for help. A lesson for all of you lone cyclists. You never know when something might happen. By the way the Kask helmet was flattened on the impact side. I wouldn’t be writing this otherwise. Anything between your head and the ground is preferable to a smashed skull. A note to Chris. Boardman, helmets are essential. The head injury alone, long term concussion and damage to hearing, tinnitus, loss of balance and frightful headaches went on for the best part of a year. Any jarring motion made my brain hurt inside the skull, almost like it was swollen. It hurt to shout, sneeze or cough let alone shake it. My other physical injuries healed quickly as normal. Believe it or not I was back on the bike after 4 weeks but after a while the head pain and balance issues made me reconsider, opting for a few months recovery. I had two MRI head scans a year apart and they showed no bleeding or damage apart from age related deterioration. That was a relief. A recent scan has also come up clear apart from a small bleed which they indicate may have been a mild stroke undetected. I am due a full body MRI scan soon and hope that shows all clear. I suspect residual damage from the accident and want to check. Have had scan. All okay.
It took two years to get back to my level of cycling and fitness sufficient to ride for 6 continuous days from Pisa to Verona across the Dolomites in September 2019.  I averaged 13mph over 550 miles with 55,000ft of ascent. Now I can barely manage 10miles on the flat. What I think happened is that I focused on recovery and managed any side issues passing them off as the result of hard training and recovery. After the Dolomite ride I was seriously tired and in need of rest. I was down to 68kg and looking rather starved. I looked like death warmed up you could say, not a good picture.  It’s quite possible that I overdid the effort and weakened my body’s natural immunity. In March 2020 I stayed at a friends’ villa in Almeria, SE Spain, on my own and cycled through the mountains. I caught the last flight back in this pandemic on 16th March. I suspect I may have contracted Covid but showed no symptoms. If so the virus could have kicked off all the background conditions I had been ignoring as cycling aches and pains. If not that virus maybe another. 
Is it possible these two conditions could have triggered the PE? Is it possible the serious hit to my head could have skewed the chemical balance in the brain and triggered the release of the PMR and GCA? This is speculation, but unless I can work out how it started I could be on these drugs for ever. Basically I seriously overdid the strain on my body and drained my last resource of resistance making me prone to anything waiting to pounce.
I started to get serious symptoms which were passed to specialists to diagnose. Everything muscular and internal seemed to be going wrong and no clear explanation as to why. It built to the recent time when my body basically was closing down. Like I said earlier, I was reduced to a foetal position out of bright light in order to get any release from the symptoms. That’s then to now and with the diagnosis I seem to be getting my body back. Nearly all the things going wrong are going right save for the residual symptoms which haven’t been fully suppressed. The leg muscles are almost functioning properly. I’m sure the strength is still there but they tire very quickly. Hopefully we’ll get there soon. Calves quite good. Glutes hurt worst but get better with use. Hams next but again recover well. Quads are next worst but improve. Worst are hip flexors. They are not used to striding. They need extra work. All improve as the drugs effect works for longer each day. It seems that the perfect balance is when there is just enough drug to last a full day suppressing the conditions whilst being fully used up just before the next days’ dose. Six weeks into treatment and I can confirm that nearly everything is working better.	
 I’ve decided to save my money on massage and correction as the effects  are largely a consequence of the contracted muscle caused by PMR. Until the Prednisolone takes full control of the condition 24/7 there is no point in the palliative effect of massage relieving the pain. It only masks the recovery of proper function of the muscle. This is quite a relief because it now explains why whatever correction and massage I used always reverted in a few months to the need for more. I need to fully understand how this disease works at the neuromuscular level and how it interferes with the proper firing of nerve synapses to relieve the contraction. When the Prednisolone finally suppresses the disease it won’t be a cure. Without knowing the cause I will have to work to reduce the dose and work out an exercise regimen to regain my fitness. Only then can I determine to what level I can return.
 Despite everything I’ve endured it has been a blessing in a perverse sort of way. I have known for years my body is not working as it should. Whatever I did I couldn’t get a handle on what was wrong. I was hoping for a miracle drug that would put it all right. Now I know what’s happened, the drug is no miracle, only something trying to stop my body going wrong. It’s actually given me a real understanding and a massive challenge to try and get back to an even fitter and better physical condition. It’s going to be an interesting period probably over a couple of years to regain even my old top level if that’s possible. This diagnosis has given me something to aim for with hope. In trying to understand how I feel both physically and mentally I am more alive today than I have been in decades. 
Maybe it’s the relief from pain, or the belief that this unpleasant and worrying phase is under control. I genuinely feel better than I have ever felt for more years than I can reckon. After six weeks on the drug it’s almost fully suppressed the two conditions. My body is working better than it has in all areas, apart from stamina and being able to work all day not tiring. It may be a false euphoria caused by relief so I shouldn’t expect too much, but it is good to feel that there is real hope of a full recovery. The sad irony is this same drug that has saved my body destroyed my fathers from his condition 40 years ago. How times change with knowledge and insight. Someone of religious bent might be giving thanks to God. I cannot claim such blind faith. It seems like a miracle, but it is all down to observation, knowledge, understanding and sheer dogged determination to not let it win. I have been given a second chance to enjoy my health and fulfil the next however many years productively. A new start with a body that is working properly. What a gift at 70.     
 
 So, that’s it.         I have put this out there for consideration. 
I hope it may help someone who is in pain, depressed and confused not knowing why everything is going wrong and not being able to put a finger on the cause or the solution.   
 Hopefully you won’t have this, but if you do I hope this helps. 
    
Over and out.   Happy cycling.  Good luck.

Rugger.bio:
I was diagnosed with PMR in May 2016, but in hindsight had symptoms that I couldn't make sense of for 6 months before that. The PMR 'relapsed' / flared over 3+ years, every time I reduced the prednisolone, however slow the taper. My CRP and ESR have always reflected periods of inflammation (See graphs in my posts). By November 2019 I felt the PMR might be in remission and I was symptom-free on 4mg, but the blood results were higher than ever. A PET-CT scan showed GCA-LVV, with aortitis and other large vessels involved. An increase in pred dealt with the inflammation, but my Rheumatologist predicted more relapses in future and I started on Tocilizumab in March 2020, just 10 days before the first Covid-19 'lockdown'! The TCZ seemed to tackle the inflammation, as I had more energy than at any  time in the previous 4 years. I was able to create a vegetable garden during 2020 & 2021, which would have been unheard of with PMR. During the pandemic I was given an extension of the NHS 52 week ration of TCZ, but this came to an end in March 2022. Even with TCZ I had a flare of the LVV and stayed on 5mg pred for almost 8 months in 2021, before starting to taper again. I reached 'Club Zero' for pred in April 2022!
I was about to 'celebrate' a possible remission of the PMR & GCA-LVV, but my Rheumatologist feared the GCA-LVV could flare if I were to be on no medication, judging by the amount of inflammation seen on my PET-CT scan in November 2019, so I started Methotrexate in May 2022. She intended to keep me on MTX for a year or so - if it suited me, but I didn't feel as well on MTX as I did on TCZ, my CRP and ESR started to rise again and aches and pains returned. After 8 months on MTX, in January 2023 I went back on 5mg pred and the MTX was discontinued. Throughout 2023 and 2024 I tapered down very gradually, and up again, but get stuck around 3mg, so that's where I'll stay at the start of 2025 - in my 9th year since diagnosis.
My other hobby, apart from gardening,  is rag rug-making, hence my alias "Rugger"!  My avatar is a circular braided rug about 3 feet in diameter. Contrary to what some people have thought, I'm female and not a rugby player or fan! I live in West Yorkshire, UK and am retired from working in the NHS.
In 2017 I helped set up the Yorkshire support group of PMRGCAuk and continue as one of the present Group Organisers.

Nextoneplease.bio:
Hi, I am based in the UK. I was diagnosed with PMR in March 2021, and  GCA in June of the same year. Started on 15mg of pred by GP, raised to 40mg by rheumatologist, and now (May 2023) down to 6.5mg a day. My most troubling symptoms currently (now that  pred is managing most of the pain), are muscle weakness and fatigue.

I am retired - I worked as a probation officer, social worker and adult education tutor. I loved working and only retired at 64 to look after my mum who had vascular dementia. She passed away in November 2019 and very soon after that, of course, we were all hit by the COVID pandemic. 

My life currently centres around my family (husband, daughters, grandchildren) and friends. Social life gradually expanding again😊 I manage a bit of cooking and gardening but am finding everyday tasks increasingly difficult.

Other conditions include myasthenia gravis, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, macular degeneration, knee replacement complicated by sceptic arthritis and bacterial endocarditis - and two open heart surgeries for mitral and tricuspid valve repair. Thank goodness for the NHS!

Update May 2023. Currently on 6.5mg prednisone daily. Have had a DEXA scan and after 10 years of denosumab injections, now only have osteopenia rather than osteoporosis. Shoulder and wrist x rays have shown severe osteoarthritis and I’ve been referred to an orthopaedic surgeon for advice. Also, my optician feels that my previously early stage macular degeneration and glaucoma have got worse, such that she’s had no alternative but to refer me to the eye hospital. Watch this space….!

GP very reluctant to diagnose PMR  due to “normal” CRP (1) and ESR (11), despite a magnificent response to steroids within 4 hours. I live in Kent (England)

PMRCanada.bio:
I'm a 62 year old woman from Tillsonburg, Ontario, Canada who was diagnosed with PMR in May/18 by my gp. Prior to diagnosis I suffered progressively worse pain and stiffness in my knees (I have pre-existing OA), and later my shoulders and hamstring and quads.  

I was put on 20mg of Prednisone by my GP on May 1/18 and within 1 day I experienced great improvement of my presenting stiffness and pain, as well as my knee pain. I remained under the care of my wonderful GP.

I got "stuck" on 9mg for about 20 months and Jan/22 started Methotrexate as a steroid sparer under the supervision of a new (good) rheumatologist. Fingers crossed as I am heading in the right direction and have been able to lower my dose in .5mg increments. I am currently tapering down to 5 mg. 

I am learning that I do not have control of what is happening in my body physically, but I can control what I eat, how much I exercise, when I rest. who I share with and ask for support from.  This is not the retirement I worked hard to earn, and I miss all those things I was previously able to do without much effort and enjoyed.  I will say I am still able to walk, swim, garden and golf (with a cart. I even manage dancing time to time. 

In an effort to connect further with other folks who have PMR/GCA, I've created an online support group with 3 others from Ontario which meets monthly via Zoom, and provides valuable connection with others who "get it".

Leslie

Marijo1951.bio: I was born on 4th March 1951. I live in north London, roughly midway between Archway and Crouch End. My last job before retirement was 15 years spent in Customer Services for Transport for London. I have 4 children, 3 daughters and a son, and 4 grandchildren - twins (boy and girl) aged 21, a boy of 17 and  a girl of 14. I'm divorced and live alone.  I was very rarely ill until I first felt the symptoms of GCA and PMR at the beginning of April 2017.  I was finally diagnosed on 31 July 2017 by Dr Pamela Mangat at the Royal Free Hospital. I had thought that I was suffering either from fibromyalgia or ME. When she diagnosed me, I had never heard of either condition despite extensive Googling. I'll never forget the relief of losing the terrible pain and stiffness within a couple of hours of my first dose of Pred. Of course there are plenty of other difficulties that don't go - above all the fatigue - and Pred brings its own side effects, but on balance I believe that being close to painfree and relatively mobile is worth everything else.

Sophiestree.bio:
I was diagnosed with Large Vessel Vasculitis in October 2020.  It took over 3 months to get there as I was not typical to Temporal Arteritis in that it did not affect the top of my head, but more from my neck downwards also affecting all the major arteries from my aorta down my legs and arms.  It has affected my liver, lungs, intestines and possibly not related, parathyroid (I do have an existing underactive thyroid and poor osteoporosis that seems to have got a lot worse) but have now had that removed, not sure I have noticed much difference.  So I seem to be an anomaly in that I did not tick the usual boxes and it was only after a PET scan that the extensive (their words not mine) inflammation was discovered. 
I had 3 days of 1 gram steroid infusion followed by 40mg daily.
The consultant suggested reducing them by 5mg each week after a month but most of my symptoms returned and so I went back to 40mg
it was then decided I should go onto Tocilizumab/Actemra which I started on 20th January, self injecting once a week along with reducing the steroids by 5mgs a week again until I get to 15mg, then revised.  The TCZ ended in August 2021 and within two months I was having a terrible flare.  
Have a lot of side effects, dizziness, heart pounding and feeling like I'm on a permanent powerplate, all of which seem to have got worse on the Tocilizumab, but it is early days, so am thinking I need to ride it out at the moment.
I think I got to the reality that maybe I won't be able to return to work for some time, when all along I have just been waiting to tell them I am ready now, hmmm not happening.  I finally fully retired in May 2023.
I am a widow living in the East London/Essex borders in the UK and have one daughter who lived in Hong Kong with her two children but returned in March 2022 due to the strict covid restrictions.  I am still on 9mg in Jan 2024 and now reducing even slower than before and waiting for my new referral to come about, 6 months so far and no sign of an appointment but have enough pred to cover Essex so not too worried about it.

Sharitone.bio:
Following a camel rodeo incident in Maqy2019, I was seeing a physio for some months for soft tissue damage. This was reasonably successful. I slightly pulled a muscle in my back on 1 January 2020 and when it got worse after 6 weeks, I went back to the physio, who kept hinting that I was suffering from stress, which was news to me. After another 6 weeks of increasingly agonising exercises,  I finally went to GP and had diagnosis of PMR - 15mg of pre, increase after a few days to 20mg, then to 25mg.
I managed to go back to work that Summer (Lockdown had been a boon in the meantime). 
By Christmas I was getting ridiculously tired and GP sent me to A&E with a growing headache in March. GCA/LVV variously diagnosed, 60 mg pred. Since then, I had Methotrexate for some months and said Goodbye to most of my hair. Could never get below 15mg Pred, so started on TCZ Dec 2021. Since Feb 2022 reducing very quickly o consultant's orders.

Charlie1boy.bio:
My real name is Paddy Taylor, and I have had PMR since December 2014.  I was started at 20mg, then moved to 30mg after three days to get the pain under control. Have been tapering slowly without GP help from the beginning; this forum, particularly the "aunties" have been more than helpful. CRP and ESR have been normal after the initial diagnosis. 
The only side effects from the prednisolone/PMR have been fatigue, lack of energy and strength.. I still manage a game each week of racquet ball, walk my dog daily, and go bell ringing twice or three times a week.
I was also diagnosed with prostate cancer in July 2016, which hasn't helped. Mostly, it is the hot sweats caused by the hormone treatment injections. These finished in August 2019, but the sweats are still continuing!
I first got to 5mg in April 2017,so it's been over three more years to get down to my current level, though I was at zero for 10 days at the beginning of October 2020, before going up again a bit.
At the beginning of May 2021, I have reduced to zero! Whether this will work out ok this time remains to be seen. It didn’t!
After a further failed attempt at zero, I finally took my last (hopefully) pred on 30th Sept 2022, making it a total of seven years and nine months on this treatment.
Now, as I write on 2nd May 2023, it is seven months on zero, so, I’m thinking I’m in remission.
As of today - 4th October 2023- I’ve been off prednisolone for one year and four days. Couldn’t say 100% that I’m in remission, as I still get the odd bad day, but certainly doing a lot better.

Viv54.bio: Started with aches and pains , a couple of years ago.Went on for a long time before I finally went to a Dr, had no idea about PMR , now after my second flare im starting to get clued up .A strange and awful illness. But due to this fantastic site i now don't feel so alone with it !

Grants148.bio: I was diagnosed with PMR June 2016

Broseley.bio: Stiffness developed in June after severe hip inflammation from January. Locum GP prescribed diazepam and massage therapy. It didn't work. GP did a blood test which gave high ESR, CRP and platelets. Put on 15mg of prednisolone to almost immediate total loss of any stiffness. However my headache and jaw pain did not completely go away so my pred dose has been increased to 40mg. A temporal artery biopsy was negative but I've still been diagnosed with GCA. I am also on calcium and alendronate as I had already been diagnosed with osteopenia. I am a smoker and must stop. This is not easy. I'm now (July 2024) down to 1/2mg . Occasionally getting some soreness in ears, tendonitis pains and stiffness in both hips. Very occasional twinges in my right temple (biopsy site).

autumnlass.bio:

December 2023 was diagnosed with Angina and had minor MI, and was hospitalised for 1 week. Two weeks later hospitalised again with pyelonephritis for 1 week, and received IV Amoxicillin for 7/7.  All satisfactory. Now convalescing!

Missus835.bio:
I was diagnosed with PMR in January 2022. It's been a roller coaster ride but with Prednisone, it's been at least tolerable. 

I've had huge muscle spasms from my hip girdle right up to my ribs and now pulling on my stomach muscles. I can barely move and now barely eat because my stomach is so tight. Like a boa constrictor wrapped around your torso.


On just touching my back, I can feel the pain. It's hard to breathe because when I take a deeper breath, it pulls right from my hips right up through my torso.

I have lost 20 lbs. over the 4 months I've been only able to eat about half portions. Under other circumstances...

Since I was unable to tolerate Alendronic Acid tablets, opted for the Zolendronic Infusion last week. Done in the chemotherapy department of one of the hospitals here in Halifax, NS. Took about 15 minutes and then a half hour afterward to check vitals, etc. There can be side effects. Not going there. Fingers crossed it helps with the bones.

Unable to take physio at this time because my spine is quite brittle and they don't want to risk more vertebral fractures (now at 6 plus two vertebroplasties). Exercise is walking with walker. I'm on the second floor, so getting outdoors is a real challenge as it takes two of us. Married to my heating pad. Currently awaiting MRI to determine which vertebrae are in need of vertebroplasties next.

I am an abuse survivor (lifetime), which has actually enabled me to cope with what I'm going through currently. 

Don't let anyone tell you "there are those worse off". There indeed are, but this is your personal experience. Present moment living helps. Worrying changes nothing.

Update Sept 18/24: 
Currently living with 10 vertebral compression fractures. The majority have happened since July 2023. Had 2 vertebroplasties done Sept. 2023. Osteo Specialist says no more. I've had one Zoledronic Acid infusion in October 2023 and scheduled for the next one this November 2024. Miraculously, got in early to our Pain Management Clinic in Halifax after a 2 year wait. Could have been 5, but I was on a cancellation list. The doctor, after squeezing up and down my spine and neck and hitting many trigger points; also hips and sides of thighs, has concluded I also have "fibromyalgia", or the newer version thereof. Essentially all my nerves are on high alert and inflammed. He would give me nothing more for pain. No shots as pain is too widedpread and is referring me back to GP who sent me there in the first place, to have my pain addressed. So my list goes on. Very unsure about his diagnosis. He would not refer me to a Neurologist. Said the ball is back in GPs court. Here am I, the monkey in the middle...so that said...
PMR, Osteoporosis, Fibro, Diverticular Disease, Cartaracts (surgeries done), Hypertesion, Cholesterol high, Generalized Anxiety, Gall Bladder shot.  At least I still am able to live alone and do all the things which that involves and grateful for it.

Thelmarina.bio:
I am female, 77 and live in the UK. I was diagnosed in June 2017 and put on 25mgs Pred. Currently I am on 7mgs and tapering slowly. I took Ibandronic acid once a month for three and a half years and after a six month break, a dexa  scan and a fractured hip I’m back on it. I am also now on Lamprazole and yoghurt to protect my stomach. I’ve had a couple of violent gastric episodes, landing up in hospital with one of them! Now I’ve been diagnosed with Diverticular disease which explains what happened. Can’t blame Pred for everything! I’m grateful for Pred because it’s given me back mobility, therefore my independence and my way of life.
June 2021. Wound up in hospital with bacterial pneumonia followed by pleurisy! Bolt from the blue and a reminder of how clinically vulnerable we are. Back again two weeks after coming out with an infected cyst. Ridiculous. However, I doubled my dosage again and received excellent treatment.
 June 2022 I had an unprovoked thrombosis in my left leg. All sorted now and I am on 2.5 mgs Apixoban twice  a day.  Anyway, hugely grateful for the care, the drugs and this amazing forum, all of which are preserving my quality of life. Onwards!

Highlandtiger.bio: Diagnosed PMR in May 2018. I live in the Scottish Highlands. Before PMR I was extremely fit and active (hillwalking, scuba diving, curling, running, pilates etc). Sudden onset of symptoms in March 2018 following upon (with hindsight) a perfect storm of stressful events. Given naproxen at first which did not touch the pain. While waiting to see GP I saw a chiropractor who began taking a history then stopped, told me he thought I had PMR and to go to see my GP. Tests pointed to PMR. Started on 20mg pred on the Tuesday. By the Saturday I was pain free. Made the schoolgirl error of thinking I was cured so went up a few mountains that weekend! Initially I couldn't see my "own" GP. Was started on a quick reduction plan which caused a couple of flares. Saw my usual GP, sharp intake of breath....."rather faster than I would have recommended”, “GPs' biggest mistake is to try and get patients off steroids too quickly". I've stuck with him since and adopted a much slower tapering approach and am now on 5mg (January 2020 - update still on 5mg January 2021...). GP had not heard of PMRGCA UK or this site but I printed off Dorset Lady's excel spread sheet to show him what I planned for future tapers. He was happy with that approach although he had not seen it before. I have obtained much more information and help on this site than anywhere else and am extremely glad I found it! Update: May 2021 4.5mg. July 2022 4mg trying to reduce to 3.5mg.

Mstiles.bio:
Hello everyone,

    I’m in Northern California.   Moved here after living in Atlanta for 45 years.  Female, age 80.  
    In December 2017 I started having severe shoulder, neck pain and head pain in the occipital area at the back of my head. Nothing helped the pain.  A rheumatologist first  diagnosed me with PMR, then GCa in 2018 and put me on 40 mg of prednisone.  I didn’t have vision symptoms. 
   In three months he fired me from his practice because I didn’t taper fast enough.   I was on my third rheumy and had finally found one who listens and was happy for me to do a slow taper, DSNS plan.  I had gotten down to 8.5 mg when she left the practice in 2020 at the beginning of the pandemic.  I tried another rheumy but she didn’t known much about PMR/GCA.   After that I treated flares myself by increasing pred and then coming back down. 
      Because  of the pandemic, fires in Northern California, some flares, and constant family and financial turmoil, I basically stopped tapering and got my prednisone  from my GP.  She is so overwhelmed and unfamiliar with PMR/GCA that she or her assistant didn’t ever discuss my refills until January of this year, 2024.  She has Moab notified me she will not refill the prednisone any more and has referred me to another medical system’s rheumatology practice.  
     I had cataract surgery for both eyes in 2022.  The process took almost a year to complete due to doctors leaving and appointments being cancelled.
      I live with my son who helps me, but  who has health, (Crohns disease),  and emotional issues of his own.  
       Five 1/2 years after diagnosis I’ve never been able to get below 8 1/2 mg. and pred is starting to show its effects. I’ve recently been having walking problems and shoulder pain.  Ive been seen by and orthopedist who diagnosed me with torn tendons in the left hip and both shoulders.  No surgery possible for the hip as an MRI showed there is muscle atrophy in the joint and nothing for the tendon to attach to.  The right knee is arthritic and not strong.  I must use a cane all the time and I’m afraid of falling. 
        In finally updating this bio,  I’m shocked to realize I’ve been on pred for so long.  I had been thinking it was only three years.   Seems I haven't plowed through the turmoil, stress, and unexpected problems of life well  enough to taper successfully. I’ve always suffered from anxiety and depression and fear of doctors, I have a therapist, but no strong support from anyone else. 
    More pain and problems in other places, getting to be a long list, discouraging.

LemonZest11.bio:
Australian woman interested in the PMR/LVV experiences and advice of others. I was diagnosed in December 2018 and have been struggling to taper ever since.  In 2020 I was diagnosed with large vessel vasculitis and, with the help of tocilizumab, managed to taper to 2mgs.  Have been battling ever since.
It is now June 2023 and I have managed to taper off prednisolone and have been pred free for 20 weeks now.  I am continuing with TCZ, and am attempting to taper my injections from 3 weekly to 3.5 weekly, and then to 4 weekly.  I am experiencing muscle and some joint stiffness but no pain.  Just waiting to see if I am OK, before extending the TCZ gap to 4 weeks. 
Nov 2023 update ... I have been off pred for 40 weeks and have tapered the TCZ jabs to 4 weekly. I feel fragile and headachy in the 4th week before the jab, but otherwise doing well.
