Feeling well, I had a routine check up with my Rheumatologist, who is a new and young woman taking over some of my retiring Rheumy's patients. Bloods revealed hugely elevated inflammatory markers. But why, with no pain? A round of tests, PET-CT, CT-Angiogram, Dexa (just to 
be sure) and numerous bloods suggested nothing sinister but a relapse of the LVV. So, 25mgs pred, weekly tcz, Bactrim x 3 weekly until I'm below 20mgs and a bone protector called Resprim Forte(sulphamethoxazole and trimethoprim) as I'm now oesteosporitic 😫. Doc is on the ball and despite the shock, I feel in good hands. I begin the taper after 2 weeks on 25mgs pred with weekly blood monitoring 🤞
21/10/24 I have tapered to 5mgs pred but my neutrophils are soooo low we have decided to stall the TCZ for the time being.  Even after stretching to fortnightly jabs, the neutrophils have remained very low.  I’ll have a blood test in a couple of weeks to see what’s happening with inflammation.
10/2/25
So the inflammation came racing back once TCZ was stopped.  After increasing pred to 15mgs, it’s taken a few weeks to get down to 10mgs pred, and inflammation is still not stable.  Rheumy has suggested I join her public clinic at Royal Perth Hospital in order to access either secukinumab or upadacitinib.  In the meantime, I am remaining on 10mgs until I see her at the end of March.  By then we’ll know if I have been given approval to join the clinic.

Gimme.bio:
Diagnosed by GP as possible PMR Nov 2022.  Classic pattern of hip, buttocks, thighs stiffness and pain, sides of knees and extreme debilitating fatigue, plus muscles became very tired after little effort.  Inflammatory markers not raised.  RA, lupus and fibromyalgia excluded.  Then Jan 2023, caught flu and triggered shoulder, neck and upper arm pain, unable to turn my head so started pred 15 mg Feb 2023 with miraculous results, completely free from pain and stiffness within hours.  After 15mg for 2 weeks, reduction to 10mg due to psych effects and then again after a week to 7.5 mg. In May reduced to 5mg as still suffering side effects.  Pain and stiffness did not start to return until 5 mg, but still 80-90% effective.  Extreme fatigue returned after dropping to 5 mg.  Vit D at 4,000 IU helped fatigue noticeably.

I blame my PMR on years of work stress and personal trauma.  Became so ill May 2021, forced to stop work and take early retirement.  Now starting to suspect that viral infections trigger a flare in PMR symptoms and also possible strong dietary correlation.  Also learned, Do whatever makes you happy (if I had enough energy).

Was always athletic and fit, ran, walked, cycled, swam, I had walked to 18,000 ft in the Himalaya when all this started.  Classic atopic family with asthma, eczema and hayfever allergies.  Have always had problems with my muscles, which I put down to sporting injuries and pattern of physio, osteopathic treatments. 

Hard to say when my symptoms first started, possibly as long ago as 2003.  I can’t pinpoint first flare, but stiffness and tiredness started in my early 40s, physio advised seeing a rheumatologist, but GP did not take very seriously.  Prescribed diclofenac, as effective as pred is now, but effectiveness only lasted a few weeks, so did not persist.  Since then, every few months, I have had a flare of same symptoms, stiffness, pain, fatigue, which lasts a few months and then disappears, although stiffness persisted.  I have an idea that the flares correlate to viral infections, but too long ago to be sure, or possibly stress.  Many visits to GP, but nothing done until GP in Nov 22.

First really bad attack happened around 2007, could hardly walk due to stiffness and pain, coinciding with flare of eczema on my arms and severe GI symptoms.  GI symptoms investigated and nothing found so labelled IBS.  I suspected diet and tried FODMAPs diet, which helped GI symptoms.  Then eliminated wheat and the pain, stiffness, brain fog, palpitations, fatigue vanished within 48 hrs.  Have been gluten free since.  Though continued to get flares of PMR type symptoms; hip girdle and rotator cuff type pain.  Stopped work May 2021, at the time, I thought due to stress and mental health, but now know that there is an underlying physical reason.  Summer 22 was hell for me, for months could not get up stairs, classic PMR Donald Duck waddle, toddler stomp down the stairs and old person groaning noises to get me out of a chair.  Saw GP in Nov 22 as wondered why I was not recovering from what I thought was a stress burnout and that is when I got a tentative diagnosis.  New GP and first one to take it all seriously.  The flare was tapering off at the end of the year without treatment by the time I saw the GP, but I got flu in Jan 2023 and all the symptoms kicked off again.  The worst it has ever been.  This time, my neck, trapezoid and shoulders, upper arms affected aswell as the hip girdle, lower back and legs etc.  I was a complete mess and could hardly move, so finally gave in and went on the pred.  

I can’t say that the pred is wonderful for me, or that my quality of life is better.  The control of pain and stiffness is slightly better than taking ibuprofen, but I hate the way that pred makes me feel.  If I could stop the pred tomorrow, I would, in a heart beat.

Diet seems to be majorly important for me.  I was prediabetic last year and when I was on the prediabetes diet, my symptoms were significantly better during that time.  When I went on pred, I went back to eating foods with low Glycaemic Index and my weight has been stable.  When I lapse, I have discovered that I am extremely sensitive to added sugar, alcohol less so, very reactive to fried high carb snacks like crisps and tortilla crisps with loads of additives.  I really suffer the next day and a day or so after lapsing.

For now, I am continuing with the pred and trying to taper, and at the same time continue to explore the diet.  I am certain that I have PMR, but I also suspect that my dietary intolerance might have worsened, exacerbating the PMR symptoms.  Lastly, many PMR sufferers are anaemic, so I plan to try some iron to see if that helps the debilitating tiredness.

In case you wonder about the screen nick, I tried about 20 names when I joined and each one I tried was already taken. I finally tried gimmestrength in frustration, which was also taken 😃, so this is what I ended up with.  It would seem that finding an acceptable user name to join the site is more difficult than finding a cure for PMR.

Updated 05 July 2023.

Blood results from 5 Sept 2023:
CRP less than 5 mg/l
ERS 14 mm/h
Rheumatoid factor less than 10 iu/ml
Anti-nuclear factor negative (less than 1/100)
Iron, B12, folate and Vit D levels OK.
T4 and TSH normal
Hb a1c 39 mmol/mol - so 9 months pred hasn't put me back in the pre-diabetes zone yet. 
Weight fairly stable but put on 2 or 3 lbs.
FBC all within acceptable range.
Neutrophils 7.84 (normal range 1.5-7.2) - slightly raised due to pred?

So on the face of it, I look pretty healthy.  So why do I feel so crap then?  I made a list of my symptoms and they covered 2 sides of A4.  Saw the nice lady GP today and she still thinks that my symptoms sound like PMR, but there is still some random stuff going on (dryness, worsening asthma and thyroid) that doesn't fully fit.  She is going to speak to rheumatology about possibility of Sjogrens and is also sending me for a neck scan to look at my thyroid.  Thyroid function was normal, but I have an enlarged painful thyroid gland, it seems.

Updated 27 Sept 2023.

Zebedee44.bio:
Hi, my name is Chrissie,  I’m living in East Sussex and have two grown up children living in Wales. As yet no grandchildren but ever hopeful. 
It’s over six years  years since I learned about this strange condition which affects every aspect of my life and I don’t feel as if I am getting any closer to the end of this journey.  I was pretty much stuck at 8mg of prednisolone for four years and finally saw a Rheumatologist who prescribed leflunomide but after waiting to have my flu jab and Covid booster before starting it, posts on this forum made me reluctant to start it. 
Since diagnosis of PMR I have had a lot of pain in my jaw and feared some extra cranial GCA issues but in 2023 a referral to Maxillofacial finally indicated mechanical problems in the joint. So I persevered in tapering my prednisolone and was quite proud of myself for getting down to 5mg. 
It wasn’t long before my body demanded more of the wonder drug that makes my life good and struggled with the nausea, fatigue and general flakiness of adrenal insufficiency. And the old aches and pains of osteoarthritis in my thumbs, hands, and wrist started making daily life very uncomfortable.  Acid reflux had caused a constant sore throat and I was referred for an MRI and gastroscopy which confirmed non cancerous polyps throughout my digestive system. 
The MRI showed an enlargement of my pituitary gland and I have had multiple blood tests and eye examinations and waiting to see the Neurosurgeons in August 2024. I am now under Endocrinology as well and waiting for a short synacthen test in August.
Early in 2024 I developed what I thought was sciatica. This has continued to get worse despite exercise and has settled in my right hip and calf. X ray shows cam impingement but I have been referred for phsiotherapy as a start point.
In July 2024 The GP ran some blood tests and these indicate anaemia which might result from a blood protein disorder called MGUS, another thing I had never heard of.  I will know more when the results are released next month. It’s been a tough year.

Lonsdalelass.bio: Hi, I am a 56 (soon to be 57) year old wife, mother and grandmother; I work part time now thank goodness, and have always been active and relatively fit before PMR struck although I was diagnosed last year with CKD. I live with my wonderful hubby and adorable collie, and our three offspring have all left home, one living across the pond in sunny Florida. Our daughter lives just down the road with our beautiful granddaughter who we see every week, and help out with childminding at times. I love it! I like walking and keeping fit when I can, also baking when the mood takes me. Its great to be in touch with so many people on this site.  UPDATE.... Aug 2022..i. now at zero pred!! Been here since May, so still early doors.  No major flares since diagnosis, unlike many on the forum sadly, so feel very lucky. Had 'blips' when I've needed to increase slightly  and taper back down, but finally got here to zero pred. Taking things slowly, and nothing for granted. Still pacing myself whilst trying to increase strength and stamina with walking a little more,  but no cycling or swimming or fitness classes yet. Have two beautiful grandchildren now.

Polywotsit.bio: A founder member of PMRGCAuk, and former Chair of Trustees, back in the day when we started this forum.   I have had PMR, but I haven't had GCA. Rachmaninov2.bio:
I was diagnosed some years ago with high cholesterol and then high blood pressure, I improved my diet including starting to use Benecol spread, but didn’t take any medication for the high blood pressure.
About three years ago I felt very unwell one evening, symptoms were numb hands and arms, numb mouth and problems with my vision.
I went to A and E where they found that my blood pressure was dangerously high, was kept in for that night and the next day when they carried out lots of tests. I was given Ramipril and Amlodipine to bring the blood pressure down and stayed on these, having bouts of excruciating migraines until approx. 5 months ago when my feet and right leg swelled up. When I saw a GP it was suggested that when I went to A and E I may have had a mini stroke.

March 2020  I was very concerned as I couldn’t walk properly or get any shoes on. Soon after, the aches and pains began! Plus all the usual, not being able to turn over in bed etc. etc. I was prescribed various medications to address the problems but didn’t take them as I felt that the Ramipril and Amlodipine may have been responsible for the aches and pains as well as the swollen legs and foot.
Even though I realised that you should not stop taking blood pressure medication without discussing it with your GP I did stop, and bought a blood pressure monitor. My blood pressure had stayed at a reasonable level until about three weeks ago when I realised that there was something very wrong with me and I stopped monitoring it because I was just concentrating on trying to find out what is wrong with me (I know that I need to start again)
Now I also have burst blood vessels in a finger on one hand and also swellings on the palm of my hand, and also a claw like other hand with  pain going up the arm and swellings on the palm.



Diagnosed with Rheumatoid Disease and PMR 2020 which are not under control . Some uncertainty about definite diagnosis.

Told by Optician that I have blepharitis approx. 2021.

Diagnosed with Scoliosis and Spinal Stenosis /Compressed Cauda Equina/Fractured Vertebrae 2022, had consultation with neurosurgeon in December 2022, operation on my spine recommended. 
Still waiting for letter and information about the operation following the consultation. Still waiting for result of DEXA scan. March 2023.

Taking 5mg Amlodipine for high blood pressure, 7mg Prednisolone for PMR, and 7  1/2 mg Methotrexate Metoject for inflammatory arthritis .

Diagnosed with Benign Essential Tremor.

Diagnosed with low functioning kidneys (Stage 3a CKD) in December 2022, no information, dietary advice or referral to a nephrologist. 

Diagnosed with anxiety and depression January 2023, awaiting CBT. 

Methotrexate paused due to a viral infection, February.

Diagnosed with high cholesterol February GP recommended statins, no dietary advice.  Decided to decline for now.

Have requested my GP to refer me for physio (for back and feet) currently being assessed March.

Physio is going to refer me to a podiatrist. 

Stopped Amlodipine, hoping problems with feet/legs may improve a little. Started Losartan 50 mg a day instead. March.

Increased Prednisolone to 7 1/2 mg a day. Increased to 9mg a day March.

Migraines, Amitriptyline 10mg 1 or 2 at night. 

24 March Heart attack.

27 March Angioplasty.

Stopped Losartan.

Neurological symptoms, trouble spelling words. 

New medication regime, many new medications. Lansoprazole 30mg 1 a day, Bisoprolol 2.5mg 1 a day, Dispersible Asprin 75mg 1 a day, Ticagrelor 90mg 1 twice a day, Ramipril 2.5mg 1 a day, Atorvastatin 80mg 1 a day, Nitrolingual pump spray when needed. 

April Cardiac Rehabilitation (Other health conditions preventing me from having Rehabilitation).

May First Homehelp visit. 

May Post MI Clinic

May Physio Review/Starting exercises for spinal stenosis. 

End of May First session of CBT.

Beginning of May Increasing Oedema, feet particularly badly affected. Finding it difficult to walk.

June 5 6 monthly Rheumatology appointment.  

June 5  Admitted to hospital with dangerously high blood pressure. In A and E for 17 hours, No sleep, very little food etc. plus heated ‘discussions’ with doctors and nurses re my medication not helping to lower blood pressure, in fact the opposite!

June 13  Medication review with GP pharmacist.

June  Assessed and approved for eligibility for pre filled Dosset Box. Hopefully beginning July 7. 

July  New medication regime.  
20mg Pantoprazole 1 a day, 10mg Prednisolone a day, 75mg Dispersible Aspirin 1 a day, 7.5mg Ramipril a day,  2.5mg Bisoprolol  1 a day,  90mg  Ticagrelor 1 twice a day, 80mg Atorvastatin 1 a day, Nitrolingual pump spray when needed, 7.5mg sub cut Methotrexate a week, 

July 4  Follow up Rheumatology appointment. Hope to find out about the possibility of being prescribed a biologic. 
My Rheumatologist has decided that I should start taking 7.5mg sub cut Methotrexate again alongside tapering Prednisolone. He also wants me to take Alendronic Acid (something I have tried to avoid) as I have osteoporosis. Will have another appointment with him in December.

September Podiatry appointment for assessment.

September 21 Pain Management appointment, referred for MRI.

October 4 MRI scan.

October 16 Telephone consultation with Neurosurgeon re possible laminectomy to help with spinal stenosis pain.

October 19 Appointment with Pain Management consultant to discuss results of MRI.  Scan shows 2 ‘slipped discs’, Options would have been a laminectomy or a steroid injection but heart meds prevent either of these, so discharged back to rheumatologist’s care. If I am able to stop taking the blood thinner in March 2024 the operation may be a possibility. Disappointed as I feel that I am back to square one. 

October 25  A and E with high blood pressure, breathlessness and dull ache in chest. Diagnosed with Angina.

Slowdown.bio:
23rd September 2023
PMR since 2015.  Current pred dose 9mg slowly reducing to 8.5mg over a month.  On Metformin since June for Type 2 steroid induced diabetes.  I lost heart over last winter,  my body became a riot of sun damage, SCCs, BCCs which all meant 'procedures' with stitches galore and Efudix, which I have used without problems on actinic keratoses.  One specialist prescribed this for a stubborn non-healing lesion on my eyelid - result was  an allergic reaction and several weeks of excruciating rawness and pain until I saw another consultant who stopped it immediately and prescribed Hydrocortisone.   Utter relief.      My biggest regret is not being able to swim in the river/sea due to healing wounds.  At least I can walk daily to gaze longingly at the waves.   And a little companion in the shape of a robin who flies to my hand to feed - well, he gets organic cheese and just can't say no. I've had 2 generations of robins, and blackbirds keeping me company.  Think it saved my sanity.

My GP finally referred me to a Rheumatologist last January - disasterous meeting.  His first words were 'I see no signs of PMR,  no inflammation indicators. Can you do this? (rising from chair; raising hands above head; etc.)  ' Yes, and surely the steroids are just doing their job at managing inflammation ...??' It got worse, he wasn't the consultant but a registrar with an agenda. ' We want you on Leflunomide, here's a leaflet, oh sorry we've run out, will send you one and make an appointment in another 6 months'.   'I'm reluctant to sign up to a drug I have very little information on and if I haven't got PMR can you suggest any other possibilities. RA?  '  but he ignored my obvious wish for a discussion and went off to see the Consultant for 10 minutes.  Icy politeness was all I could manage by then.    Still waiting for leaflet and appointment.  

Two strokes 2020, 2021, TIA March this year - wonderful Hospital doctor who linked these to possibly being migraine induced as MRI scans have never shown damage.  I haven't had migraines until the last couple of years, but they certainly became a very upsetting, if extremely colourful,  experience - optician called them the Prisoners Cinema type where the visions continue for around 20 minutes even with closed eyes.  Five consecutive  
 evenings of these last year at a time of stress, resulting in confusion and inability to use computer.  More research into this, ongoing.    I can only hope for a less, shall we say, 'eventful' and discombobulating winter ahead.

Insight329.bio: My name is Joy.  I am in the Midwest, USA.  I’m 64 years old  and female.  I was diagnosed with GCA in May, 2017 by a Psychiatrist.  Yes, you read that right.  I was sitting in my best friend’s office, who happens to be a Psychiatrist.  She asked me how my headache was and I told her it was a BEAST and that I could not get rid of it.  I then pulled back my hair and said “And, what is this?” showing her the beaded vein by my temple.  Her eyes bugged out like a cartoon characters, she took a piece of paper, wrote on it, passed it to me and said “Go call your GP now and tell them that Dr. (her name) would like you to get Joy in today for possible G.C.A”.  I secured an afternoon appointment, my GP apologized for missing the diagnosis when I was there 2 weeks prior for the headache (and showed her the vein).  She explained that she had never seen G.C.A.  Although she did not feel qualified to treat it, she started me on 40 mg of Prednisone, and secured an appointment the next day with a Rheumatologist.  That was on a Monday and by that Thursday I had the biopsy, which was positive.  (Diagnosed with PMR February, 2018.) Previous medical history: low grade ovarian cancer (1990), Nissen Fundoplication for bleeding ulcer/hiatal hernia (10+ years ago).  I’m grateful to have found this forum!!!

Greensleeves.bio:
Diagnosed with PMR in September 2012 , 
aged 50, …..started 15mg Prednisilone  in January 2013 ……
, resisted until the pain and stiffness became unbearable.
 
Successfully tapered off over 2 years, as advised by GP, but became very ill , as so often happens I still had PMR. 
Restarted at 30mg this time. 
Saw a rheumatologist, had all relevant tests , asymptomatic, no raised inflammatory markers . 
Tapered to 5mg and stayed there for 3 years on advice of rheumatologist as a maintenance dose possibly forever. 
 Still hoped  the PMR would burn itself out and adrenals would wake up. 
Managed to decrease further to 3mg , then 2mg myself. 
Stayed at 2 mg for a long while, it was hard but I managed to care for unwell close family and my grandson. 
Everything went haywire when I caught Covid  in December 2020 and had to increase sick days Pred to 10mg , also had the fallout of 10 days of Dexamethasone in hospital after I was admitted with adrenal crisis. 
Developed Long Covid . 
Trying to stabilise again, currently doing an 7.5/7  taper . 
PMR has returned,  back at 10mg , haven’t been right since Covid. 
Can’t get below 7.5 without feeling like flu and the early days of PMR. 
Had a devastating bereavement, many health issues accompanying the grief . 

Covid infection again , requiring 20mg Pred October 2023.
 Completely wiped out, have to start tapering again once stable. 
Extremely disappointed. 
Can’t get below 7.5 without a flare or the feeling of the warning signs of adrenal crisis. 
10mg seems to be the lowest I can manage with all the stress , ill health and grief. 

I managed to stabilise at 7 but tapering to 6.5 was awful, 7 mg isn’t quite cutting it now. 
Have stayed at 7.5mg for several months after having a TIA in early September, finding it impossible to lower the dosage. Hardening of the arteries seen on head MRI . 
Pain I can cope with to a degree , but have developed hip pain and irrational anxiety when on anything any lower than 7.5mg , which in turn creates more anxiety. Any stress results in nausea and feeling ill like flu . Pred , both a life saver and a demon.

Tiggy70.bio: I was diagnosed with PMR in August 2020.  I had the classic symptoms of pain in my shoulders and then my hips which developed quickly in just over three weeks until I could barely dress myself.  I had chest and hip X-rays which were normal and blood tests which revealed an ESR of 44.  My Gp immediately put me on a dose of 15mg of Prednisolone.  After about 4 days I felt much better but had difficulty sleeping as I was told to take the Pred at night.   I changed this to a breakfast dose and my sleep improved.   My first Pred reduction was after 3 weeks to 12.5 mg.  Looking back I definitely had a flare on this dose but was told to persevere by the Rheumatology consultant.   After another three weeks I was told to reduce to 10mg.  Again another flare and back up to 12.5.  This has been the way my Pred journey has been.  I quickly realized from the posts on health unlocked that slow and steady is the way to go.  I struggled badly to get below 10mg of Pred but using the DSNS method I made it to 8.5 mg.  My Rheumatologist is insisting I reduce now by .5 mg per month.  I’ve tried twice to get down to 8 but the pain returns.  I am currently on 8mg but experiencing the worst pain since diagnosed in August 2020.  The consultant now wants me to take Methotrexate.  I am really against taking this drug yet.  I have type 2 diabetes and I’m currently on 9 prescription medications including Risedronate which the consultant insists I take and won’t refer me for a Dexascan.  I’m currently in a bad place with this illness and will write a post to hopefully get some advice.  I have read posts every day since Joining the forum in October 2020 and this site has been invaluable to me.

Bluey-1.bio:
Treatment started for GCA 29/6/22. Was ill with a cough, sore throat, headache 2 weeks prior to diagnosis, jaw pain when eating and weight loss. GP requested bloods; referred for MRI scan. Six hours later vision in both eyes disturbed intermittently. Twenty minutes later in eye casualty. CRP 171; ESR 129. Given aspirin / 60 mg steroids; contact made with stroke team, rheumatology. 
30/6 - 4/7, vascular scans, ECG, MRI. Stroke/TIA ruled out 2/4. GCA confirmed 5th July. Gradual tapering of pred  plus regular blood tests for CRP/ESR.
August 2023 - TIA due to atrial fibrillation. Blood thinners (Edoxaban) and beta blockers added to the mix.
June 2024 - Increasing breathlessness, saw GP, bloods indicated heart failure! Echocardiagram, heart monitor showed atrial flutter and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
September 2024 - ablation, beta blockers changed .
February 2025. Currently on 6.5mg pred.

Miserere.bio:
I have not suffered any long term illness until now, so I have always been reasonably healthy, always a walker and I follow a healthy diet.  I began to notice some stiffness in my hips during my daily walk in February - after I had the first Pfizer vaccine.  This worsened to include shoulders and occasionally eased.  After the second jab it got worse and I reported it as a side effect of the vaccine to my dr who suggested blood tests and then suggested it could be PMR.  A second blood test taken and I am now on 15mg Prednisolone - started a week ago.  Symptoms 70% improved - I force myself out to walk every morning and I do a couple of yoga/somatic sessions each day.  Hoping to learn from others' experience and share any experience I have along the way.
March 2023 - Referral to an orthopaedic surgeon raised regarding osteoarthritis in the knee and awaiting appointment.  Physiotherapy - 3 sessions so far - some exercises have strained ligaments.  
November 2023 - aortic valve regurgitation following echocardiogram.
I have suffered IBS-C for most of my life - I remember being taken to hospital with a 'stoppage' when I was pre-school age.  After that fed with castor oil, ex-lax chocolate, syrup of figs, senokot - anything mother could think of.  I have always suffered from constipation which GP eventually put down to IBS-C.  Improved somewhat following paleo/keto diet (very low carb) but after trying carnivore diet for a few days which improved things, I reintroduced other foods (mainly vegetables) and it has got much worse - hard, dry stools which are painful.  May have to return to Laxido.

Diagnosed with PMR late Feb 2018 after 5 months of symptoms which began after a virus infection. Began 15mg Prednisolone,and upped to 25mg in April. It took three attempts to get past 10 mg. .5 mg tapers from then.  Presently on 7.5mg pred August 2019.

Sunnie2day.bio:
Retired lady aged mid-60s, half American (born there to ex-pat parents, worked entire career there as well), whole British (Scottish) retired permanently to NE Scotland.

I also have Essential Tremor (now moving to my voice, blast it) and what my consultant calls the mildest case ever of rheumatoid arthritis both thanks to the RHS, plus Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (car wreck 1973 related nerve damage), and finally, PCOS.

A MedicAlert bracelet with the engraving as doctor suggested (Angina With Normal Coronaries, Recurrent Pericarditis) has been a huge boost to confidence knowing 'if something happens' a First Responder will be able to read the bracelet and access my health record. I never take it off and have a spare in the jewellery box.

Heather1957.bio:
Started having chest pains in 2016 which even I diagnosed as angina. however the first GP I saw decided it was acid reflux! I waited a week or 2 and saw a more switched on GP who had some knowledge of cardiology and he decided I should be referred to a cardiologist. Anyway, in January 2017 I had an angiogram (followed by a stroke 4 days late but 98% recovered) and there was a blockage in my LAD and it was decided that due to the position of this blockage I would need a bypass.
In June 2017 I had a single bypass using my mammary artery and was discharged after only 4 days.
Recovery went very well and all was fine until September last year (2021) when I started having some 'twinges', in October they became worse and I realised I had angina pain again and after a phone conversation with my GP was told to go straight to A & E which I did.
I appreciate that A & E doctors cannot be experts in everything but from 2 pm Monday until about 9 am Tuesday I kept being told that I had acid reflux (deja vu). I stuck to my guns and was eventually admitted to a ward later that Tuesday.
I was seen by a cardiologist on the Wednesday who told me I would be transferred to another hospital for an angiogram which I was on the 22nd October (Friday)
The angiogram revealed a blockage of the RCA which to their surprise was badly calcified so I had to have the artery drilled out to fit 2 stents.
I was kept in overnight and discharged on the Saturday.
3 full months later I am feeling good but very aware that things can change.
My motto is listen to your body as you know it better than anyone else and stick to your guns if you know something to be true even if the doctors tell you it isn't.

Alison_L.bio:
I had a silent heart attack in 2018 (age 56), which was picked up by my GP when I saw her after 3 weeks of "gastro problems". I spent most of the next month in hospital, coming out with a shiny stent and a shinier ICD. In 2019 I had a second angioplasty with a balloon inserted. Current (2023) meds: Eplerenone, Lansoprazole, Aspirin, Candesartin, Isosorbide, Carvedilol, Rosuvastatin, Empagliflozin, Vitamin D. Also Furosemide as & when.

Since the heart attack in 2018 I have piled on the weight, despite going to the gym and regular cycling (2022 did London-Brighton) and other exercise, and am now Type II Diabetic, with Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy in my feet and lower legs. GP not interested. The Empagliflozin is both a heart and diabetes drug, so not on any other drugs.

Suddenly went deaf in right ear Nov/Dec 2020. Had MRI Feb 2022, and diagnosed with small/medium sized Acoustic Neuroma. This had grown from 1cm to 1.5cm (mainly a cyst that was growing on the tumour) in the 6 months to Sept 2022, so was offered translab surgery which I turned down (partly because I couldn't afford the recovery time), so was offered Fractionated Stereotactic Radiotherapy (FSRT) instead. 5 weeks of short daily blasts Mon-Fri. Completed Feb 2023. Now awaiting follow-up MRI in May to see if that's worked. UPDATE: MRI showed the cyst  had shrunk. Neuro-oncologist very happy and will see me after a repeat MRI Feb 2024 (a year after radiotherapy). Woop woop! 2024 UPDATE: MRI showed continued shrinkage, and neuro-oncologist still very happy. Next repeat MRI early 2025.

stevejb1810.bio:
Hi.  

My name is Steve.  At the end of April 2017, I retired from full time employment after 42 years spent working in the Pharmaceutical industry.  Six months into my retirement, in the middle of October, I had an angiogram and 8 days later, one day after my 60th birthday, I had a triple CABG at the excellent Basildon Cardiothoracic Centre.  

Like just about everyone else, I didn't see my triple CABG coming.  I was in denial right up to the point the cardiologist told me I needed a triple bypass and that they were going to admit me immediately, and even then it took a bit of 'digesting'!  I have some family history but thought I was reasonably 'healthy'.  Like many, I was moderately active,  a little overweight, liked an occasional beer or glass of wine but I probably sat in front of one screen or another a little too much.  Even so, my blood pressure was in the normal range and I was taking a low dose statin for raised cholesterol, but nothing to write home about, at least so I thought.

So, now I'm something of a new man.  I exercise 5 days in 7, eat very healthily (and dropped out the cakes and biscuits), I've lost 8kg in weight and I'm fitter now than I have been in years.  After just 4 months (I'm writing this in February 2018), I'm back working (for myself), I've travelled long haul and life is beginning to feel 'normal'. I try not to take anything, certainly not my health, for granted.  I have to guard against trying to do too much and being some sort of superman.  I'm a work in progress and expect to be that for a very long time to come.

MummaSoap.bio:
I experienced symptoms during my last trimester with my first child but due to a hot summer and never experiencing pregnancy before, I didn’t realise. After the birth of my son the swelling in my feet and ankles slowly left me but it was a further 2/3 months before I could fit my feet into my own shoes again!

Between September 2018 and January 2021 (when I was diagnosed) I had a second child in March 2020 but continued to experience tiredness and feeling weak and occasions of my heart racing or feeling more prominent in my chest. I also had to have emergency surgery for a hiatus hernia in December 2020 but about 10 days after surgery when I was still experiencing palpitations I was sent for a chest X-ray and CT scan. My CT scan showed a dilation of my heart and I was referred for an echocardiogram. The day after this appointment I returned to A&E with shortness of breath and palpitations again after paramedics were called and my heart readings were showing that I was becoming tachycardic every time I readjusted my position, stood up or moved around. Later that evening I was admitted to CCU and the next morning my diagnosis was explained to me. My EF was 37% and I was told I had borderline severe heart failure and probable dilated cardiomyopathy. I was also told that I couldn’t have any more children. I began medication and regular monitoring and my heart started to show signs of recovery and my EF increased to 58% which was fantastic news!!

In May 2021, 4 months later, I received the shocking news that I was in fact 20 weeks pregnant! In August 2021, my symptoms were rapidly getting worse and a repeat echocardiogram showed that I had lost 6% of my heart function in 1 week so the decision was made and my miracle made her way into the world at 32 weeks. 

In November 2021 I had another repeat echocardiogram and it showed my EF had increased to 48%. I’ve had a repeat echocardiogram in June 2022 and my EF was at 45% but I’ve had a recent change to my medication (November 2022) so I’m hopeful that things will improve soon and hopefully with less side effects.

Healthyheart1.bio: I was diagnosed with angina in October 2018. It was a shock to me. I couldn't understand how I could have the pain so bad and the spray wouldn't work. As time passed I was diagnosed with vasospastic angina. The pain made more sense to me although it didn't change it. I was given the usual meds aspirin , nicorandil, a statin that I couldn't tolerate, isosorbide in steps up from 10mg I have now settled on 30mg twice daily, diltiazem 240xl, and ranolozine 500mg twice daily. It took 18 months of going to a&e in and out of hospital various times with no end in site. I am now coping a  lot better,  I know my triggers, cold, windy days, hot days, I could be stood in a  draught. In the early days I was so tired and if I was woken up out of a deep sleep I would be in really bad pain that wouldn't be eased with my gtn spray. I still get pain at rest and when I wake up but since having the drug ranolozine it has allowed me to get on with my life with some normality.

Sljp0000.bio:
Been getting a few pains on exertion. Nothing major. Had a CT heart scan which came back with severe calcification in 3 vessels. Score 958. Awaiting Angiogram. Scared stiff, has all come out of the blue. Only found out last night 6/7/22.  No real discussion with gp or cardiac nurse, just an email dropped in my inbox. 

Update: now had Angiogram which showed severe narrowing in 3 arteries and some veins. Being urgently referred to Glenfield hospital, Leicester for Triple/Quadruple bypass surgery. Feeling scared but grateful it's been found. God is my comfort.

Push forward 5 months. After surgery I had a saddle pulmonary embolism, a thrombus in my heart and clots in both lungs.

 Recently found out my diaphragm isn't working due to nerve damage during surgery.

Feb 23 had angiogram to be told none of my grafts have worked. Heartbroken. All that for nothing. Back to square one. Except now I have heart damage, messed up diaphragm, numbness from scars and sternum pain. 

Waiting to discuss the way forward. Feeling sad.

Now had 4 stents in 3 arteries. Praying they stay tissue/clot free unlike my grafts. Got to stay positive.

Update. Tests show Phrenic nerve was severed during surgery. Will always have a paralysed left sided diaphragm which means my breathing is compromised. 
Sternum not healed.

Felt some pain in left forearm whilst swimming on 23 Nov 2022. Shrugged it off as muscle strain. Felt very sick in changing room. Once that eased walked home and nodded off on sofa.
Felt worse in afternoon. Rang 111 who called ambulance. Taken to A&E where told I was having HA. Pumped full of pain killers and, after a long night in A&E, was admitted to CCU. Had angiograph later that day. No stents inserted but given cocktail of drugs. Bisoprolol, clopidigrel, dispersible aspirin and Atorvastatin plus existing BP meds Felodipine and Telmisartan. A bit later on given lansaprozole to help stomach.
Now getting used to meds and dealing with emotional impact.

Snowdrops_17.bio:
I had a heart attack February 2019,  2 Angioplasties and 3 stents!
In June 2019 had an MRI to confirm peripheral artery disease in both legs and a blockage, 13 cm, in my left leg! 

I still tire much easier since then and still experiencing symptoms in my legs which can become painful especially in my calves!  Going for walks, house work or gardening is more a chore now then relaxing! But I don't give up and bat on! 
Osteoarthritis in my hands, fingers and feet doesn't help but glad it's not severe! But I do feel my hands aching a lot after pruning shrubs or washing-up which I did in my previous job as kitchen porter!
But I have a big family, we are 14 members altogether and I have 5 grandchildren 🥰 
I moved from Germany to England with my husband, to North Yorkshire, January 1993 but since 2009 I am living on my own! I can't believe it's over 30 years now! I still have close family in Germany as well, which is wonderful  and I call them as often as I can! 
Last year December 2022 we suddenly lost my only older sister Conny! That was a massive blow to all of my family and me and after I retired from work I finally had proper time to grief and reflect after 8 months of her death! 
Life is mixed with happiness and loss, achievements and rewards good or not so good jobs afterwards! 
But we are alive and whilst we are alive lets give thanks to God for every new day he is giving to us!
